text: President Obama said were at war over a
year ago and he directed me and others
to put together a 65 country coalition
we have put together six or nine lines
of effort that we're pursuing against -
including cutting their finances going
after their propaganda cutting off the
foreign fighters where we can I mean
their whole series of things we've been
doing for a year so President Obama
specifically said we're at war with
these guys now there's a heightened
urgency to dealing with the foreign
fighter component of it because of
what's happened obviously in Paris and
in Beirut and in Cairo and in Cairo in
Egypt because of the airliner but this
is not a surprise that - has that
capacity
they've always promised it and we've
always been alert to it the problem is
that it's very difficult much harder you
know somebody wants to strap themselves
in the suicide vest and go out and kill
themselves you can find a crowd of
people somewhere in the world to hurt
it's much harder to be a hundred percent
everywhere all the time to stop that so
the key is to eliminate - at its
headquarters in its home where it has
declared this phoney caliphate and that
is in Syria and Iraq and that's what
we're doing there controlling 25 percent
less territory we've liberated
communities the Iraqi army is beginning
to move it's going into Ramadi it's
taking back they've taken back Sinjar
we've we've got major efforts going in
Syria now and I think Russia is now more
focused on - as a result of what
happened with the airliner so you know
things are beginning to squeeze in them
President Obama always said this will
not be quick it's going to take a period
of time but we are methodically and I
think now systematically growing the
ability to be able to limit
- his ability to grow within Iraq and
Syria and that will ultimately have an
impact on what they can do elsewhere
he's been quite clear about the
methodology and he insisted or the
stamina of what they're doing but if
there was a major mass casualty attack
in the United
states of this scale do you think
President Obama would still not sanction
a major escalation against Islamic state
well I'm not going to speculate about
one major this or that what we're doing
is trying to prevent those attacks from
taking place and the president has put
in place what I think we all believe is
a strategy that can guarantee that
there's something there behind the
liberation that police are being formed
and trained so you can hold the
community you've got a military that's
being retrained and and and built up in
their capacity we've already seen what
happens when the United States of
America is in occupies the country and
spends a bunch of years and then you
know you've got to you there's got to be
a developed capacity behind you that
obviously didn't happen sufficiently
before because the Iraqi army just
folded and walked away when the when -
came in to Mosul and other parts of
North Western Iraq and so we want to
make certain that as we go along here
that doesn't happen again and you're
also working very hard on a political
solution in your view mr. secretary do
you think the Russians are wedded to the
Syrian regime or to Bashar al-assad
himself I did it to the former do you
think there's a chance now that mr.
Assad could leave power well I'm
convinced the Russians are not wedded to
Assad himself I think they are they're
wedded to the notion that they don't
want to see Iraq they don't want to see
Libya they don't want to see the leader
go down or leave and then there's chaos
afterwards nor do we by the way well the
great lesson of Iraq is don't disband
the army don't send the institutions
home which is what happened so we are we
are all united in our desire to keep the
institutions of governance in Syria
whole but that doesn't mean Assad he's a
person not in this shouldn't be an
institution and and obviously he has to
be part of a transition if you're going
to end the war because Assad is the
magnet attracting these jihadis who come
from all over the world
to fight with the with - and others to
get rid of Assad and and you know we're
convinced that in a systematic careful
way over the course of the next month's
- will continue to feel the pressure
continue to be compressed into a smaller
entity and ultimately will be degraded
and destroyed and just briefly you've
set a timetable for a transition of 18
months but realistically how long do you
that's for an election the political
nature of the transition is is within
six months that process we hope will
begin in earnest sometime in December by
January 1st somewhere in there we want
the negotiation to get started to put to
test the proposition that Russia and
Iran are serious about a real transition
and real peace in Syria now we'll learn
pretty quickly whether that can work or
not work but if Assad does not
transition there will not be an end to
the chaos of Syria
so within weeks we might see something
we have a chance to see whether or not
this political process will take life
and whether or not the negotiating teams
can be selected come together and engage
in earnest with all of us by the way in
the process urging them and coaching and
and and and helping to help shape the
process but Syrians themselves are going
to have to decide that part of the
future and we will know I think in
December January whether or not that is
taking shape Thank You mr. secretary
appreciate it
